body: retest this please
ok, I'll go ahead and merge. Please file a JIRA for automation.
Retest this please.

If I understand you correctly, the test purpose is to validate that we can replace a transformation with the same name. 
In that case, the assert at the end doesn't validate that.
1. Even if the replacement fails, this assert still passes:
`assertThat(names, hasItem("original_application/custom_name"));`
2. This assert will always pass as no one mentions "custom_name2" as a name:
`assertThat(names, hasItem("original_application/custom_name"));`

Maybe a better assert will be to validate that the transformation instance is now the `ReplacementTransform` and not the `OriginalTransform`.

What do you say?

The proto change is reasonable to me, I'm assuming that either Ken or you will resolve the changes needed for pr/3924

Based upon the list of parts, I grouped them into the three areas I believe they should go:
- beam-model-core:
  -  Modeling of a Pipeline and pieces of it
  - Standardized transform payloads
  - primitives
  - non-primitives (only ones which are shipped with Apache Beam, users creating their own should package and ship their own)
  - Standardized UDFs
- beam-model-job-management:
  - Job submission and management (Job API)
  - Artifact upload
- beam-model-job-execution:
  - Artifact retrieveal
  - Model of bundle processing instructions (ProcessBundleDescriptor)
  - Standardized execution-only instruction payloads (like data plane read instructions)
  - Setting up the SDK harness (Provision API)
  - Control plane for bundle processing (FnControl)
  - Multi-purpose data streaming (FnData)
  - Logging
  - execution-time only transform payloads

LGTM, thanks.

That division makes a lot of sense to me, except having Artifact Upload and Artifact Retrieval separate seems a bit odd (but I could live with that, as long as they share a common definition of Artifact).
Yes, I was thinking the same thing now that you mentioned it that the a common Artifact definition should fall under beam-model-core.
It's a bit of a strange place for it, given that it has no use until the Job API, which does not appear to be part of the core model

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/13555814/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/13555814)

Changes Unknown when pulling **b7a116e95a4d0d49f725c936f942f42a255a341b on markflyhigh:python-split-postcommit** into ** on apache:master**.
Artifact upload is part of job management though.
Please fix the test failure: https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_MavenInstall/14768/org.apache.beam$beam-sdks-java-core/console

We should think hard about whether the notion of artifacts (which seem
similar in spirit to environments) should be in the core model, especially
if they're per-step or anything like that. I agree that submitting
artifacts belongs as part of the job API (though perhaps not distinct from
submitting the job itself) and fetching them part of the execution API.

On Tue, Oct 3, 2017 at 5:03 PM, Lukasz Cwik <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Artifact upload is part of job management though.
>

To follow up, I'm OK with leaving `checkpoint()` for parity with Java until we add `try_split`. Of note, the former can be called concurrently with DoFn.process, but *also* is called whenever resume is returned and in this case requires stricter semantics. 

Regarding the mixin/documentation issues, here's a better idea: Rather than take a contentless `DoFn.RestrictionTrackerParam` identifier, have the RestrictionTracker parameter have a default argument that would be a `RestrictionProvider` instance. This new type would hold all the methods for dealing with restrictions (element -> initial restriction, restriction -> restriction* splitting, and restriction -> tracker, and restriction coder) and of course be a natural place to put all the documentation as well.
Thanks @wcn3 !

Also, what's the reason for adding this to util ? Do you think this will be useful for other I/O connectors ?

How about just adding this to io/gcp/spanner ?

cc: @lukecwik @kennknowles

Thanks.

Added 'RestrictionProvider' and updated documentation accordingly.

PTAL.
Retest this please.

The impetus for disabling the roundtrip was SQL, which passed for me prior to opening this PR, so that's progress.

retest this please
Thanks @tgroh. PTAL

Agree with @robertwb that there's a decent chance the TBD `Environment` bit on UDFs may reference things like artifacts. It seems like a bit much to include the whole classpath, or to narrow the list down effectively, but there may well be special cases, like when the user specifies additional resources to stage. I think "core" might be a loaded/generic term that makes us more hesitant to include things than we need to be.
I think we should run the seed job from this PR first to make sure it succeeds, so that we can always run it from master if it does not.

Unfortunately this will not work on the Dataflow runner (which is the main user of PubSub). The Dataflow runner has it's own internal version of the PubSub connector (including a custom watermark tracker for PubSub), so this code will simply not run when using Dataflow.
